pageData.text: This experiment investigates the concepts of heat transfer and <button class='glossary-text'>calorimetry</button>. The student calculates the <button class='glossary-text'>specific heat</button> of carbon steel and compares it to the accepted value. The student then determines percent error.

Calculate the <button class='glossary-text'>specific heat</button> of a metal.
Calculate the percent error of the experimental specific heat.

pageData.text: Manufacturers search for metals with small <button class='glossary-text'>specific heat</button> capacities so when the stovetop is turned on, the instrument heats up in a reasonable amount of time. Some manufacturers use copper because it conducts heat much better than other metals, such as aluminum and stainless steel. However, a pure copper pot or pan can be costly. To circumvent this, some manufacturers choose to just include a copper coating on the bottom of the pot or pan to take advantage of the benefits of copper.

When manufacturing the handles on the pot or pan, the material considerations are quite different. The ideal handle will have a high specific heat capacity since these materials will heat up slowly and avoid user burns. This is the reason why some pots or pans have handles made from different materials than the actual pot or pan. Every decision made when designing these cooking instruments is influenced by science and it is up to the manufacturer to determine the cost-benefit of the information science provides.

pageData.desc: A cube of aerogel on display.
pageData.altText: A large copper cooking pot with two lateral handles and a lid.

pageData.text: Heat is thermal energy caused by the movement of atoms and molecules. As <button class='glossary-text'>kinetic molecular theory</button> states, atoms and molecules are in constant motion and their distance of travel is limited to the space between adjacent particles. In gases, this space between particles is considerable, whereas in solids, there is less space between particles. Nevertheless, the molecules in a solid remain in motion despite being in a fixed position relative to each other.
A property usually associated with thermal heat is temperature. Temperature and heat are related, but they do not refer to the same quantity.

text: Temperature is the average kinetic energy of the particles in a material.
Heat is the total energy of the particles in the material.

pageData.question: Based on the definitions of temperature and heat, which of the following comparisons is true?

options.text: The water in a swimming pool at 25°C has more heat than a cup of tea at 40°C.
An ice cube has a greater temperature than boiling water.
A child’s body has more heat than an adult’s body.
The air at night has a lower temperature but more heat than the air at midday.
A sandwich at 30°C has more heat than the same sandwich at 35°C.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Although lower in temperature, there is much more water in the swimming pool than in the cup of tea and therefore it has more heat, or total energy.

pageData.question: Which of the following substances is most likely to have the greatest molecular movement, such as is described in the kinetic molecular theory?

options.text: water vapor
an ice cube
a copper coin
vegetable oil
sea water

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: As kinetic molecular theory states, atoms and molecules are in constant motion and their distance of travel is limited to the space between adjacent particles. In gases, this space is considerable, whereas in solids, there is less space between particles.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body:
A property usually associated with thermal heat is temperature. Temperature and heat are related, but they do not refer to the same quantity.

• Temperature is the average kinetic energy of the particles in a material.
• Heat is the total energy of the particles in the material.

For example, the water in a swimming pool at 25°C has a lower temperature than a cup of tea at 40°C, however, because there is much more water in the pool than the cup, the pool water has more heat. Remember, heat is thermal energy caused by the movement of atoms and molecules. As kinetic molecular theory states, atoms and molecules are in constant motion and their distance of travel is limited to the space between adjacent particles. Even the molecules in a solid remain in motion despite being in a fixed position relative to each other.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body:
A property usually associated with thermal heat is temperature. Temperature and heat are related, but they do not refer to the same quantity.

• Temperature is the average kinetic energy of the particles in a material.
• Heat is the total energy of the particles in the material.

For example, the water in a swimming pool at 25°C has a lower temperature than a cup of tea at 40°C, however, because there is much more water in the pool than the cup, the pool water has more heat. Remember, heat is thermal energy caused by the movement of atoms and molecules. As kinetic molecular theory states, atoms and molecules are in constant motion and their distance of travel is limited to the space between adjacent particles. Even the molecules in a solid remain in motion despite being in a fixed position relative to each other.

pageData.text: cs, is an intensive property of materials. It is defined as the amount of energy required to raise the temperature of 1 g of material by 1 °C. For example, water has a specific heat of 4.184 J/g °C. That is, 4.184 J of energy is required to raise the temperature of 1 g of water by 1 °C. The relationship between energy, specific heat, mass, and temperature is shown in Equation 1.

pageData.altText: Equation 1: q equals C sub s times m times delta t

pageData.text: The variables in Equation 1 are defined as follows:

text: q is energy
cs is specific heat
m is mass

∆t is the change in temperature
(∆t = t final – t initial)

pageData.text: All materials have a distinct, measurable specific heat.

<button class='glossary-text'>Calorimetry</button> is the method of measuring the amount of heat transfer within a closed system. The device in these types of investigations is a calorimeter. One critical design element of all calorimeters is the calorimeter must be insulated so that energy may not enter or exit the calorimeter’s system. This experiment employs a coffee cup calorimeter composed of 2 foam cups.

In this experiment, the calorimeter contains a known mass of water at a known temperature. Then metal washers at the temperature of boiling water are added to the calorimeter. Finally, the resulting temperature of the water in the calorimeter is measured. When a metal washer is placed in the calorimeter, it transfers energy to the water until the entire system establishes thermal equilibrium. Energetically, this is expressed in Equation 2.

pageData.altText: Equation 2: q sub water equals negative q sub metal

pageData.text: Since the metal loses energy in this experiment, it is a negative quantity. Substituting <button class='resource-text'>Equation 1</button> into Equation 2 produces Equation 3.

pageData.altText: Equation 3: C sub s sub water times m sub water times delta t sub water equals negative begin paren C sub s sub metal times m sub metal times delta t sub metal end paren

pageData.text: Using this equation, the of the metal, cs metal, can be calculated.

pageData.question: Calorimetry measures which of the following?

options.text: heat transfer within a closed system
the average kinetic energy of an open system
the average kinetic energy of the particles in a material
the total energy of the particles in a material
the specific heat of a material

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Calorimetry is the method of measuring the amount of heat transfer within a closed system.

pageData.question: Calorimeters are closed systems. Which of the following best describes a closed system?

options.text: Energy may not enter or exit the system.
Energy may enter the system but not exit.
Energy may exit the system, but not enter.
Energy may enter or exit the system.
Energy enters the system until the specific heat is reached.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The calorimeter must be insulated so that energy may not enter or exit its closed system.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Calorimetry is used to measure how much heat is absorbed or released by a system. The device in these types of investigations is a calorimeter. One critical design element of all calorimeters is the calorimeter must be insulated so that energy may not enter or exit the calorimeter’s system.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Calorimetry is used to measure how much heat is absorbed or released by a system. The device in these types of investigations is a calorimeter. One critical design element of all calorimeters is the calorimeter must be insulated so that energy may not enter or exit the calorimeter’s system.

pageData.desc: This map depicts the workflow for this investigation. To prepare, construct the calorimeter and cut 3 lengths of string. To begin the activity, measure the mass of the water sample and add it to the calorimeter. Then, measure the mass of the metal washer. Next, heat the washer in boiling water. Then, record the temperature of the water in the calorimeter. Next, transfer the heated washer to the calorimeter. Then, record the calorimeter’s water temperature at regular intervals. Repeat this process for two washers together and for three washers together. Next, calculate the change in temperature for each trial, the specific heat of the metal for each trial, and the average specific heat of the metal. Finally, calculate the percent error of the results.

Then, record the temperature of the water in the calorimeter. Next, transfer the heated washer to the calorimeter. Then, record the calorimeter’s water temperature at regular intervals. Repeat this process for two washers together and for three washers together. Next, calculate the change in temperature for each trial, the specific heat of the metal for each trial, and the average specific heat of the metal. Finally, calculate the percent error of the results.

This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is the major safety concern of this investigation?

options.text: Water is heated to boiling temperatures.
Strong acids and bases are used; they should not be mixed.
Most of the equipment is glass, which can break.
Keep long hair and sleeves away from open flame.
The isopropyl alcohol is highly flammable.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the difference between the heat and temperature of a substance?

options.text: Heat is the total kinetic energy; temperature is the average kinetic energy.
Heat is the average kinetic energy; temperature is the total kinetic energy.
Heat is the total kinetic energy; temperature is the total potential energy.
Heat is the total potential energy; temperature is the total kinetic energy.
Heat is the total thermal energy; temperature is the total chemical energy.

assestmentData.question: Aluminum has a specific heat of 0.9 J/g°C. How much heat must be added in order to raise a 10 g aluminum block by 10 °C?

options.text: 9 J

assestmentData.question: Aluminum has a specific heat of 0.9 J/g°C. If 500 J was added to a 2.5 g aluminum block at 50 °C, what would be the final temperature of the block?
If 50 g of water in a calorimeter rises to 37 °C after absorbing 400 J of energy, what was the original temperature? The specific heat of water is 4.184 J/g°C.
Which of the following best defines the specific heat of a substance?

options.text: The amount of energy required to raise the temperature of 1 g of material by 1 °C.
The amount of energy required to raise the temperature of the material to 100 °C.
The total amount of energy of the material.
The average kinetic energy of the material.
The amount of energy released by the material when it is combined with water.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following equations accurately describes the relationship between energy, specific heat, mass, and temperature?

options.text: q = C<sub class = 'bodysubscript'>s</sub> • m • Δt
q = (C<sub class = 'bodysubscript'>s</sub> • m) / Δt
q = C<sub class = 'bodysubscript'>s</sub> / (m • Δt)
q = (C<sub class = 'bodysubscript'>s</sub> • Δt) / m
q = C<sub class = 'bodysubscript'>s</sub> • (m / Δt)

assestmentData.question: Calorimeters must be insulated to prevent heat from entering or exiting the system. Which of the following best describes the insulation method of the calorimeter you will construct in this investigation?

options.text: two stacked foam cups
a test tube wrapped in paper towel
a small test tube placed inside a larger test tube
an Erlenmeyer flask in a water bath
a plastic cup wrapped in twine

You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read the entire procedure before getting started.
Clear a work area for all lab materials.

Cut 2 foam cups to approximately half height. Construct the calorimeter by placing 1 foam cup inside the other. Cut a piece of card stock or cardboard that will fit over the top of the cup, and cut a hole in the center to fit the thermometer.
Cut 3 lengths of string, each about 18 inches. Set these aside.

In this activity, you will experimentally determine the <button class='glossary-text'>specific heat</button> of carbon steel by measuring the heat transferred from steel washers to the water in a calorimeter. Then, you will calculate the percent error of your result by comparing the value to the accepted specific heat value of the metal.

pages.title: Specific Heat of a Metal (22 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Specific Heat of a Metal (22 steps)

pageData.text: Place the third foam cup on the electronic balance, and tare. Pour tap water into the cup until approximately 40 g of water is dispensed. Record the actual mass, mwater, in Data Table 1.
Pour the water into the top cup of the calorimeter.
Place the cardboard lid atop the calorimeter, and insert the thermometer through the center hole, making sure that the bulb is in the water. Set the calorimeter aside.
Using the scale, measure the mass of 1 metal washer, mmetal, and record it in Data Table 1 under the “1 Washer” column.
Thread a length of string through the hole of the washer until the washer is hanging from the center of the string (see Figure 1).
Repeat Steps 4 and 5 using 2 metal washers and then 3 metal washers.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: String threaded through the holes of 2 washers

pageData.text: Pour tap water into a pot to about half full, and set the pot on the stove.

Place the single washer on the string at the bottom of the pot. Wrap the doubled length of string around the heat-resistant spoon, and lay the spoon across the top of the pot (see Figure 2). Be sure that there is enough string to allow the washer to be submerged in the water. Make sure that the strings are accessible and away from direct heat so that you may safely pull the washers out of the boiling water.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Washer in a pot with the doubled string wrapped around the handle of a wooden spoon, balanced across the top of the pot

pageData.text: Heat the water in the pot to a rolling boil.
When the water in the pot is boiling, retrieve your calorimeter and record the temperature of the water, tinitial water, in Data Table 1.

Once the water in the pot has been boiling for at least 2 minutes, turn the stovetop heat off. Unwind the string of the single washer from around the utensil, then use the string to transfer the washer from the boiling water to the calorimeter. Do this as quickly as possible while maintaining safety.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Since the washer was immersed in boiling water, we will assume the temperature of the metal washer to be 100 °C.

Once the washer is flat at the bottom of the calorimeter, gently tug on one end of the string until the string is completely removed from the calorimeter. Replace the calorimeter’s lid and the thermometer.

Slowly move the calorimeter in a small circular pattern to swirl the water inside. Note the increasing temperature inside the calorimeter until it peaks, which should occur within a minute. Record that highest temperature, tfinal, for both the water and the metal in Data Table 1.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Remove the washer from the calorimeter, and discard the water. Dry the inside of the calorimeter.
Repeat Steps 8 and 9 to add the set of 2 washers to the water on the stovetop, and return the water to a boil.
While the water comes to a boil, repeat Steps 1–3 to prepare the calorimeter water for the trial with 2 washers.
Repeat Steps 10–14 to complete the data collection for 2 washers.
Repeat Steps 15–17 for the trial with 3 washers.

Calculate the change in temperature using the formula ∆t = tfinal – tinitial for each data set, and record the results in Data Table 1. Note that ∆t will be positive for water and negative for the metal.
Calculate the of the metal washer for each trial by using , and record each in Data Table 1.
Calculate the average of all 3 trials, and record the results in Data Table 1.
Calculate percent error by using Equation 4

pageData.altText: Equation 4: Percent symbol error equals begin paren begin vertical slash C sub s sub steel minus average C sub s sub metal end vertical slash forward slash C sub s sub steel end paren times 100

text: Discard the foam cups and calorimeter lid.
Dry the thermometer and metal washers.
Allow the water in the pot to cool before discarding the water in the sink.

pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

Specific heat of steel, cs carbon steel (J/g °C)

pageData.title: Questions
text: Why is it necessary for a calorimeter to be insulated?
Why is performing multiple trials of an experiment a best practice in science?
Which of the three trials had the most error in the specific heat calculation?  Why do you believe that this is the case?

This map depicts the workflow for this investigation. To prepare, construct the calorimeter and cut 3 lengths of string. To begin the activity, measure the mass of the water sample and add it to the calorimeter. Then, measure the mass of the metal washer. Next, heat the washer in boiling water. Then, record the temperature of the water in the calorimeter. Next, transfer the heated washer to the calorimeter. Then, record the calorimeter’s water temperature at regular intervals. Repeat this process for two washers together and for three washers together. Next, calculate the change in temperature for each trial, the specific heat of the metal for each trial, and the average specific heat of the metal. Finally, calculate the percent error of the results.

data.title: Calorimetry
data.content: The method of measuring the amount of heat transfer within a closed system

data.title: Kinetic molecular theory
data.content: Atoms and molecules are in constant motion and their distance of travel is limited to the space between adjacent particles

data.title: Specific heat
data.content: An intensive property of materials, and defined as the amount of energy required to raise the temperature of 1 g of material by 1 °C
